title: Gift Interfaces
subtext: Co-Teacher for class on the architecture of gift-giving in product design at SFPC
descriptionMd:
A class for the [School for Poetic Computation](https://sfpc.study/) on the architecture of gift-giving to incorporate as inspiration into product design (as opposed to the tradition of infinite scale) and how we can create more interfaces, infrastructure, and cycles of giving to foster interdependence.
 
My co-teacher, [Elan Ullendorff](https://elan.place/), and I taught two sections in the Winter 2025 session to 37 students. We followed a very experiential style and modeled the entire syllabus around giving gifts in various capacities:
 
- Give a gift to yourself
- Give a gift to a stranger
- Give a gift to a loved one (generic gift objects vs. meaningful gifts, gift cultures)
- Give a gift to a community or public (mutual aid, what can gifting learn from design / what can design learn from gifting)
- Give a gift interface to the world (gift rituals, gift products, gift objects, gift infrastructure)
 
For our final class, we held a potluck and gift wrapping party where we “wrapped” (documented) all the gifts given throughout the class and wrapped them up into a gift interface that we made for the students. After all of the gifts were wrapped, we played a White Elephant-esque game to unwrap them all and present the gifts students made to each other.
